Topic.Title: Bull or Bear

Message.Msg: Actually, I do think Jeff understand what I am saying. There is a reason that Amazon has built more distribution centers as it has expanded the breadth of product offering. There is a reason that it canceled monthly Prime. There is a reason that it is offering 3P financing. Jeff knows the economics. He just has no incentive to make everyone else aware of the limitations... Amazon will have to pull a NFLX in time and change its pricing model. Like NFLX, the brand impact will be profound.

Message.Title: United Kingdom to go after AMZN on Tax Avoidance - JUST ANNOUNCED
Message.Msg: By Christopher Hope, Senior Political Correspondent 10:35AM GMT 04 Jan 2013 Foreign companies like Starbucks and Amazon which have avoided paying large corporation tax bills in Britain lack "moral scruples", David Cameron has said. The Prime Minister said he was going to make “damn sure” that foreign companies like Starbucks and Amazon which have been found to avoid legally paying a large corporation tax in the UK paid their fair share. Mr Cameron was speaking weeks after MPs on the Public Accounts Committee accused Starbucks, Google and Amazon in a high profile report of “immorally” minimising their UK tax bills. Last year Treasury minister David Gauke caused a row when he told The Daily Telegraph that people who paid cash in hand to tradesmen, allowing them to avoid VAT, were "morally wrong". Mr Cameron was asked by a business audience in the north west of England on Thursday why “Starbucks and Amazon” were allowed to avoid paying large corporation tax bills, given that they have a large presence in the UK.

Topic.Title: If the big mutual funds do the right thing, the outflows will reverse...

Message.Msg: Tech, Speaking of outflow..... help me understand something or correct me if I'm wrong. All this Fed printing that is suppose to be trickling down to the consumer via banks, which it is not, has to be going somewhere. The money that is not being lend out cheaply to AMZN and INTC etc. is being used by banks/hedgefunds/investment houses etc. to buy stocks. I assume from the amount of money printed these outfits have to be leveraged to the max...no? Once the rates go up or the trades start going against them or Fed printing stops taking the floor out from under the market they will have to liquidate in droves or they'll go insolvent. Am I wrong in this thinking? Selling will lead to more selling and more selling. Anyone with a 401k in stocks won't ride it all the way down again like the did in '08 which leads to more selling. Is this the Armageddon that Sybs warns us about? - PJ

Message.Title: Prediction
Message.Msg: I am not trying to start an argument. I am just trying to have a little fun. Here is my prediction for AMZN over the next few months. In the next 10 trading days AMZN breaks out to a new all time high on slightly greater than normal volume. Several trading days later it closes below 260. Right before earnings it trades back up to its all time high. Earnings are announced and it craters. The rest of the year it trades lower (see also: AAPL late 2011). AMZN will be down 40% at some point this year. One thing I strongly believe is that all high flyers eventually crater. They don't fade or trade flat...they crater. This one will too and it will be even harder than AAPL. Nobody wants to be left holding the bag on a stock where management doesn't care about investors or profits and spends endlessly on expansion for profits that will never come. You can walk on the edge of a razor for only so long. It is coming. It is just fun for me to guess when.

Message.Msg: Holy cow is this stock overvalued. If anyone is long, count your blessings and SELL now. For anyone who is bullish, have you even looked at the valuation people are putting on it? Book value is about 7.5 billion and the market cap is 117 billion!! That means people are projecting 110 billion in future profits when last year AMZN made 632 million. This means AMZN would have to earn 632 million in profits for the next 170+ years to realize the value people are placing on it now. Absolutely crazy. This stock is worth about $23. If you're still not covinced, look at the insider trading: Over the last 12 Months there have been 165 shares Purchased and 1,023,349 insider shares Sold. Dont be stupid and just sell. You'll thank me later.

Message.Msg: Bond markets won't fail. Fed will monetize 100% of flow if necessary and intervene as necessary. Those shorting bonds right now will be in a world of hurt because retail is happy to park money there short term (safer than putting cash in banks to be used for derivatives...) and the Fed will buy all it needs to buy to maintain debt service interest viability. The tape is being painted everywhere and technical traders are buying all the wrong stuff across the board. I've never seen a misalignment of fundamentals and technicals as large as this... Not even close. Either the big boys rotate or the market will collapse over the next quarter because there is no real conviction and support under the technical driven valuations...

Message.Msg: First, that isn't news. It's already known that Amazon has been developing said platform. The reality is that Google dominates the segment (including mobile) and a very large cross section of the economy would have no use for advertising through Amazon. Traditional retailers have no incentive to help Amazon... Only small etailers (eBay and Amazon 3P) players. Just a new hype storyline to distract from the fundamental reality that the economics of the core physical goods retail business do not scale as was anticipated...

Topic.Title: If you all can't see what will happen next week you are blind!

Message.Msg: I hope it announces a phone. More misallocation of capital would be helpful to the shorts. Of course, one of the analysts might actually look at the trend in net profits and find the real correlation (and it isn't "investment"). Or, they might look at incremental revenue and gross profit CapEx productivity trend over time (if CapEx was really generating economic leverage, one would expect to see both the quarterly trend of revenue and gross profit declining as a percentage of CapEx or lagged CapEx over time... In reality, CapEx the reverse is occuring). Most AWS investments are NOT long lived assets. In fact, that massive computational infrastructure will be less competitive as next generation 14nm Haswell based servers come on the market -- much higher computational power per unit energy, which is critical to the economics of Cloud hosts... Google and others entering will have an advantaged cost structure because it didn't overinvest in power hungry servers to run its platform. Wonder what would happen to Amazon if any analyst had the guts to actually downgrade it...

Message.Msg: Is trading on a trailing PE of 100 then they must blow out the profits this quarter. That's profits not sales. There is no way they can get a blow out profit which will get them to a trailing PE of 100. Sales might be thru the roof but profits must explode this quarter to make it work. The current PE of 3000 looks at best to be down to a trailing 1000 not 100. Cloud is starting to get really competitive will SAP-IBM-ORCL-CRM and many more starting to get a good foot hold. Selling razor blades on line won't get you anywhere. A real time PE of 1000 becoming the new number in place of the hyped 100 will be great fun to watch. so many sellers so few doors.
